entry.title: Embedded Finance in SAP: SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity with J.P. Morgan Payments
entry.content:
Enterprises are rethinking how to connect banking capabilities with ERP processes to maximize business value. Key questions include:

  • How to make payments, reconciliation, and cash visibility seamless and fully integrated between banks and the ERP system?
  • How to adopt innovations like real-time payments or real-time cash balances without launching a new IT project every time a banking service gets added?
  • How to unlock the combined value of invoice and payment data in the ERP alongside the cash and financial data held by banks?

SAP and J.P. Morgan asked themselves the same questions. And as a result decided to collaborate and partner even closer to bring more value to shared clients by better integrating the capabilities of both by accelerating adoption of SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity (MBC) to deliver J.P. Morgan bank services embedded in ERP processes.

With SAP MBC, corporates get direct, standardized access to J.P. Morgan banking services directly integrated into their payment and cash processes. As a result corporates can scale new services faster, without custom builds and with minimal ongoing maintenance and benefit from the seamless and many times real time data flow to get the decision advantage crucial in todays fast and ever changing business world.

What you can expect

  • Seamless connectivity: Integrate J.P. Morgan services via SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity to connect your SAP ERP to J.P. Morgan Payments using standardized, bank-approved channels.
  • Automate payments and reporting: The J.P. Morgan Payments Adapter 2.0 supports file-based payments (ACH, checks, virtual cards, wires‚Äîincluding FX) and real-time payments across the U.S., EU, UK, Australia, Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong.
  • Real-time insights: Access instant reporting and reconciliation, view account balances and transaction details, and track payments through advanced APIs.
  • Easy implementation: Prebuilt adapters and help you go live quickly and securely
  • AI-powered treasury: Leverage SAP‚Äôs cloud data foundation and AI-driven capabilities to interact with J.P. Morgan and elevate treasury operations.

Who can benefit

  • New and existing J.P. Morgan clients using SAP S/4HANA (Public Cloud, Private Cloud, or On-Premise) or SAP ECC (6.0+)
  • Organizations operating on J.P. Morgan Access, with support for multi-bank reporting across non‚ÄìJ.P. Morgan DDAs
  • Teams seeking flexible connection options through SAP MBC to tailor integrations to specific business needs

This collaboration meets clients where they are simplifying connectivity while strengthening control and visibility at the same time, and accelerating access to new banking innovations, all embedded in SAP ERP processes.

Want to know more?

    • https://www.sap.com/germany/products/financial-management/multi-bank-connectivity.html 
    • https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_MULTI_BANK_CONNECTIVITY
  • J.P. Morgan SAP Integration:
    • https://partners.jpmorgan.com/sap_s4hana.html
  • SAP and J.P. Morgan Partnership:
    • https://digital.jpmorgan.com/jpmorgan-with-sap/index.html

Still want to know more?

entry.title: Introducing the WalkMe-based alternative in-app help user experience: What and How to Activate
entry.content:
Good news! With the 2508 upgrade, SAP has released 12 standard, non-customizable WalkMe flows, ideal for accountants and sales representatives (no extra license; activation needed). 

SAP recently acquired WalkMe, which is a digital adoption platform that overlays your application to guide users how to navigate workflows step-by-step. Think of it as a tutorial with little bubbles that pop up and tell users where to click and what to input in fields when they're trying to complete a process, like create a sales order. 

Turn this on once and your users get step‚Äëby‚Äëstep help in 33 languages* for high‚Äëimpact sales and finance tasks: Sales (Find/Edit/Create Order, Set Delivery Block, Add Shipping Instructions), Finance (Find/Change/Reverse/Copy Journal Entry, Customize Line Item View, View Related Documents), plus a homepage tour. These Smart Walk-Thrus are especially helpful to new users who need in-app guidance. Subject to change.

Persona

Embedded Flows

Apps in Scope

 General Accountant

  • Find a Journal Entry
  • Customize Line Item View
  • Change Line Item in a Journal Entry
  • Reverse Journal Entry
  • Copy a Journal Entry
  • View related documents in a Journal Entry

Manage Journal Entries - New Version (F0717A)

 Sales Rep

  • Create a Sales Order
  • Find a Sales Order
  • Edit a Sales Order
  • Set a Delivery Block
  • Add Shipping Instructions

Manage Sales Order - Version 2 (F3893)

 All Personas

  • Welcome to My Home

MyHome

 
*For more information like the available languages, please see SAP Note 3609634.

Note: If you are using SAP Enable Now, the WalkMe-based alternative in-app help user experience or WalkMe Premium is not available.

Activate (2‚Äì3 minutes): 

  1. Replace "Shell-home" with "#Shell-startGUI?sap-ui2-tcode=FTG_EXTERNAL" in the URL address to reach the configuration page within your customizing tenant (development/quality). This is a quick shortcut to reach the configuration activity page.
    1. Alternatively, navigate step-by-step to the configuration activity page:
      1. 2SL Customers with SB: Navigate to app "Manage Your Solution" -> Configure Your Solution -> Filter for "Application Area" - Application Platform and Infrastructure"; "Sub Application Area" - "General Settings" -> Basic Settings -> Configuration Steps -> Activate Features -> Configure
      2. 2SL & 3SL Customers with CBC: Navigate to app "Implementation Activities" -> General Settings-> Cross Application -> Activate New Features->Activate Features -> IMG Activity (clock with check symbol)

  2. Select feature: APS_UI_WME_INTEGRATION. Click 'Activate/Deactivate Feature' button near the top.
  3. Create/select transport if prompted. Name Transport to your liking. Close.
  4. Confirm State turns from red to green. Try the flows in dev before exporting to test and prod.

What happens next:

  • Open apps like Manage Journal Entries - New Version or Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and click the question mark icon at the top of your page to open the WalkMe menu. Click on the Smart Walk Thrus under the Tours tab and you‚Äôll see the bubbles guiding each step.
  • Notify the relevant users (ie. accountants and sales reps) how to find this and use this.

If you're interested in more WalkMe capabilities, like custom flows, analytics, and cross-app functionality (SAP and non-SAP apps), contact your SAP Customer Success Manager to find out more.

Have questions? Let‚Äôs chat in the comments!

entry.title: SAP MDG: Based on Grouping, Tax Number is Mandatory
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Note: This blog does not include execution screenshots.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to make the Tax Number field mandatory for specific Groupings. The logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Target Groupings: ZSGP, ZSGC
  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 001
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: Tax Number is Mandatory !!!
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the specified groupings are selected, the system enforces the presence of a Tax Number and raises a custom message if it's missing.

Code:

 

  METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
    CALL METHOD io_model->read_entity_data_all
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname    = 'BP_HEADER'            
        if_active      = abap_false            
        i_crequest     = id_crequest            " Change Request
      IMPORTING
        et_data_entity = DATA(lt_data).        " Data for Entity Types
    .
    READ TABLE lt_data INTO DATA(ls_data) WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = ' ' struct = 'KATTR'.
    ASSIGN ls_data-r_t_data->* TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lt_data>).
    LOOP AT <lt_data> ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<ls_data>).
      ASSIGN COMPONENT 'BU_GROUP' OF STRUCTURE <ls_data> TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<lv_group>).
      IF <lv_group> IS ASSIGNED AND
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGP' OR
         <lv_group> EQ 'ZSGC'.
        READ TABLE lt_data INTO ls_data WITH KEY usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_TAXNUM' struct = 'KATTR'.
        IF sy-subrc <> 0.
          et_message = VALUE #( ( msgid = 'ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS' msgty = 'E' msgno = '001' ) ).
        ENDIF.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.


SAP S/4HANA SAP Master Data Governance ABAP Development 

Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.

entry.title: Integrating SAP Datasphere with S/4HANA in ECS
entry.content:
Integrating SAP S/4 HANA with Datasphere in ECS:

Introduction

In today's data-driven business landscape, seamless integration between enterprise resource planning (ERP) systems and advanced analytics platforms is crucial for unlocking real-time insights and driving informed decision-making. SAP Datasphere, a cloud-based data management solution, offers powerful capabilities for data modelling, federation, and replication. SAP Datasphere integration enables SAP S/4HANA system and the organizations to harmonize data from core business operations with broader analytics workflows, all, while maintaining security and compliance.

Objective of this guide is to serve as a walkthrough guide for integrating S/4HANA system  with SAP Datasphere. However, please note that this guide is for information purpose only and the configuration steps in customers‚Äô responsibility should be followed up by the customers accordingly.

Architecture Diagram

Prerequisites for Integration

Before diving into the setup, please note that, for the convenience of this guide and to be in sync with the terms, here on, we will assume S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition at ECS as S/4HANA system. Which also implies customer‚Äôs current landscape (when referred as on-premise) is ‚ÄòECS‚Äô- a managed private cloud.

  1. SAP Datasphere Service Instance: Customer should have already completed the onboarding of SAP Datasphere. It runs on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
  2. Data Provisioning (DP) Agent:  Required for handling remote table data flow between on-premise and cloud. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  3. SAP Cloud Connector: Required to securely expose on-premise systems to the cloud without opening firewalls (reverse invoke) used for replication and live data flow connections. To be requested and have it provisioned accordingly.
  4. Network and Access: All applicable secure network connections between S/4HANA and Datasphere based on relevant dataflows to be taken care.
    Ex: CC for inbound dataflows from BTP to ECS and outbound internet proxy for outbound traffic from ECS to Datasphere. Also IP allowlisting for the DP Agent server and likewise.

4.1       IP allowlisting Process:

In order to connect ECS instance to datasphere tenant, it requires public IP associated with customer network‚Äôs internet proxy of the ECS servers to be added in IP allowlist tab in datasphere.

This is the public IP of their CGS proxy server. Customer can follow KBA 3643152 to get this public IP.

After getting this IP, log in to Datasphere tenantÔÉ† System ÔÉ† Configuration ÔÉ† IP Allowlist ÔÉ† Trusted Ips

 

  • SAP Notes and Add-ons: Implement relevant SAP Notes (e.g., 3283282 for CDS views, 3016862 for ABAP integration) in S/4HANA system and ensure the DMIS add-on is available for replication scenarios.
  • SICF services for live connection : Ensure all SICF services under the node /sap/bw/ina are activated in the S/4HANA system.
  • User Permissions: Administrative access in Datasphere, S/4HANA, and BTP

Integration Steps

The integration process involves configuring connectivity, setting up agents, and creating connections in Datasphere. Here's a detailed technical walkthrough

Step 1: Set Up Spaces in SAP Datasphere

  • Navigate to Space Management in Datasphere.
  • Create a new space and assign users to it. This space will host your data models and connections.

 

Step 2: Register and Configure the Data Provisioning Agent

  • In Datasphere, go to System > Configuration > Data Integration and create an On-Premise Agent.
  • Note the agent details: Name, HANA server (host), port, username, and password for messaging.
  • On the DP Agent server:
    • Run ./agentcli.sh ‚ÄìconfigAgent in the /usr/sap/<SID>/dataprovagent/bin directory.

    • Select SAP HANA Connection > 7. Connect to SAP Datasphere via JDBC.

 

  1. Specify the details according to information provided by customer:
  1. Name of the agent instance.
  2. Set " true" to use an encrypted connection over JDBC.
  3. Specify the hostname and port for the  SAP Datasphere  instance.
    • Hostname: <instance_name>.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    • Port Number: 443
  4. As SAP Datasphere is situated outside the ECS network infrastructure, a proxy is required for HTTPS communication. Define the default CGS proxy host - proxy:3128 (no authentication required)
  5. Provide the authentication credentials for the HANA User for Agent Messaging.
  6.  Confirm to save the agent connection settings. With that any existing agent connection settings are overwritten.

  • Restart the DP Agent.
  • Enable required adapters (e.g., ABAPAdapter for S/4HANA).

 

Step 3: Configure SAP Cloud Connector

  • To configure cloud connector we need the information of Datasphere‚Äôs internal Subaccount details. This can be found under Datasphere tenant, System ÔÉ† Administration ÔÉ†Data source Configuration ÔÉ† SAP BTP Core Account

        

 

  • If the email ID which will be used to setup cloud connector is not visible under the Subaccount User header, use the Change/Add Cloud Platform User option to the respective ID.
  • Under the Live Data Sources header select the ‚ÄòAllow live data to securely leave my network‚Äô option
  • Under On-Premise Data Sources header add the location ID you will be using in your cloud connector if any.

 

  • Add the subaccount in Cloud connector using the Subaccount ID, Region Host and user information from above.
  • Add the same location ID as configured in the previous step.

  • Add your on-premise S/4HANA system in the Cloud Connector:
    • Use HTTPS and RFC protocols.
    • System type: ABAP.
    • For HTTPS ‚Äú/‚Äù URL path needs to be exposed for all Paths and Sub-Paths
    • For RFC protocol add resources as below-
      • ‚ÄòDHAMB_‚Äô and ‚ÄòDHAPE_‚Äô with prefix for CDS view extraction.
      • ‚ÄòLTAMB_‚Äô and ‚ÄòLTAPE_‚Äô with prefix option for accessing tables with SLT.
      • ‚Äò/SAPDS/‚Äô with prefix option for accessing data with ODP.
      • Add RFC_FUNCTION_SEARCH with exact name option for all three options.
  • Ensure both RFC and HTTPS resources are reachable.

Step 4: Prepare S/4HANA for Connectivity

  • Create a TCP/IP RFC connection in S/4HANA using program ID IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER.
  • Register the program at the OS level: rfcexec -a IM_HANA_ABAPADAPTER -g <Hostname> -x SAPGW<Instance no.> -s <SID> &.
  • Test the RFC connection.

Step 5: Create the Connection in SAP Datasphere to S/4H

To create live data connection from datasphere to backend S4 system in ECS, it uses SSH tunnel via Cloud connector

In your Datasphere space, select System > Configuration ÔÉ† Data Integration.

  • Go to Live Data Connections (Tunnel) click on ‚ÄúManage Live Data Connections‚Äù  A window opens click on ‚Äú+‚Äù a pop up opens, select SAP S/4 HANA

  • For live data: using a Tunnel connection enter the Location ID maintained in Cloud connector
  • Input application server details, system number, client ID, SID,
  • Provide S/4HANA username and password.

 

 

 

After you click on Ok it adds the connection

 

Step 6: Set Up Data Flows and Models

  • Use Remote Tables for federation or Replication Flows for data replication (supporting initial and delta loads via CDC).
  • Import CDS views using the Model Import Wizard to automatically bring in metadata and semantics.

entry.title: SAP Commerce Cloud Q3 ‚Äò25 Release Highlights
entry.content:
In the third quarter of 2025, SAP Commerce Cloud introduced key enhancements designed to improve conversion, accelerate innovation, and empower data-driven decision making. Discover new AI-powered capabilities, enhancements to SAP Order Management Services, and SQL View Gateway.

We invite you to explore these SAP Commerce Cloud updates from the last three months by joining our Q3 2025 Release Highlights webcast to stay updated on our latest advancements.

We have the Customer Experience Connect event next week, where we showcase how the latest AI-infused SAP CX solutions optimize operations, generate action-ready insights, and deliver delightful experiences at every step of the customer journey.

Also, check out the Q3 release from the entire SAP CX portfolio.

Now, on to the SAP Commerce Cloud highlights from Q3 2025.

Insightful

Smarter recommendations with real-time stock visibility

The AI-based Shopping Agent now has product stock awareness to allow merchants to configure if out of stock products are displayed in the product recommendations that the Shopping Agent returns. This can lower abandoned carts and improves the customer experience when shoppers know an item is in stock.

Merchants can also configure if they want to allow answering questions about bulk quantities being in stock, an important feature for B2B transactions. The real-time stock visibility increases transparency, boosting conversions with relevant recommendations and improving customer trust.

Check stock on bulk quantities with Shopping Agent

Intelligently optimize catalogs for conversion

Leverage AI to quickly update product information, such as attributes or descriptions, based on system triggers or changes. The Catalog Optimization Agent also reviews product images and recommends enhancements. As a safeguard, a human is in the loop to review the recommendations and publish back to the Commerce catalog.

The Catalog Optimization Agent improves discoverability and conversions, while reducing the manual effort in editing product descriptions.

Settings for Catalog Optimization Agent

 

Connected

Empowering Unified Commerce with Central Order Service

The release of Central Order Service for SAP Order Management Foundation introduces a robust foundation for Unified Commerce, seamlessly integrating online and offline transactions. This paves the way for omnichannel scenarios like BORIS (Buy Online, Return in Store) and BISRO (Buy in Store, Return Online), offering greater flexibility in the customer experience.

 

Additionally, the Central Order Service empowers businesses with a comprehensive 360-degree view of customer purchase histories, enhancing personalization and customer engagement.

 

The rollout of API V3 for SAP Order Management Foundation significantly enhances the solution's performance and scalability, ensuring that it meets the dynamic needs of modern commerce.

 

Automatically push real-time product availability updates to external systems

The Availability Push feature in SAP Order Management for Sourcing and Availability enables proactive delivery of real-time product availability updates to external systems, such as web shops and marketplaces.  

 

This ensures that these external systems always have the latest stock information, reducing the risk of order cancellations due to outdated data. Tailored updates can be configured based on specific channels, products, and frequency, allowing for efficient communication by sending only changes in stock levels.

 

Increase data accuracy and ERP compliance

The Type Code feature for SAP Omnichannel Sales Transfer and Audit implements a robust validation process for ERP type codes, ensuring that only valid codes are transmitted to the ERP system. Each customer can configure a list of acceptable type codes, preventing invalid codes from being processed and halting transactions until corrections are made by an auditor.

 

The feature includes a user interface that facilitates the configuration of valid codes, default settings for critical fields, and options for handling optional fields without triggering false validation errors. Invalid type codes will be flagged as critical errors, and clear, actionable error messages will guide users in correcting discrepancies. Additionally, this system accommodates customer-specific mappings and customizable settings, promoting accuracy and reducing transaction-related issues.


Ensure only validated, customer-specific type codes flow into your ERP with flexible configuration and transparent error handling, resulting in fewer transaction failures, streamlined audits, and improved operational efficiency.

Adaptive

Data Unlocked: Fast, Secure, and Flexible SQL Access for SAP Commerce Cloud

With SQL View Gateway, customers gain self-service access to SAP Commerce Cloud data for efficient analytics, reporting, and integrations‚Äîaccelerating insights and driving smarter business outcomes.

Our new real-time database replicas provide you with direct SQL access that let you build dashboards, enable internal workflows, send information to Data Lakes and more, without affecting your Production database.

You will be able to manage who can access data, the scope of data available, and introduce full separation by creating up to 20 different replicas with independently scaled computes, URLs, IP Filters and authorizations.

SQL View Gateway is provided as a self-service option in the Cloud Portal that you can purchase through Consumption Credits.

 

SQL View Gateway

New APIs Drive Greater Self-Service Efficiency

Scaling Configuration API for sandboxes enables automated scaling and consumption credit savings. The API provides more control for tech-savvy DevOps teams while reducing repetitive Cloud Portal work and possibility for errors. It can retrieve the current scaling, schedule actions such as hibernating or waking environments, and enable scripts to enforce off-hours policies.

Cloud Portal API saves time and can scale dozens of endpoints without added effort. The API exposes endpoint configurations, including Maintenance Mode, for programmatic control. Customers now have API-based automation to turn maintenance on/off for every endpoint in an environment.

SSL Certificate Management API allows for faster operations, fewer mistakes, lower outage risk, and scalable governance. By integrating with your CA/SCM and updating endpoints via API, there are no more manual swaps. Automating the management of SSL certificates is safer and less prone to mistakes.

Framework Update release

We are pleased to announce the availability of the Framework Update with the September 2025 update release! Gain access to the latest functionality provided by Java 21 and Spring 6, while running the most secure and high-performance version of SAP Commerce Cloud. This is compatible with the Composable Storefront update that was released at the same time.

Please register for the SAP Commerce Cloud Tech-Focused Update webcast on October 22 for more details on this and other topics.

For more details on the above release features, check out the following resources:

  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Ready Kit
  • Performance Optimization Best Practices
  • SAP Commerce Cloud update cycle
  • SAP Commerce Cloud Release Navigator single access point to release content

SAP Help Portal

  • SAP Commerce Cloud What‚Äôs New

 

Please share your feedback in a comment and follow our SAP Commerce Cloud topic page to connect with the community!

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I‚Äôm covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results ‚Äì Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‚Äëcentric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I‚Äôll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points ‚Äì like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations ‚Äì go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances ‚Äì short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted ‚Äì and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you‚Äôre moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results ‚Äì Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it‚Äôs crucial to have full transparency into what‚Äôs actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it‚Äôs difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product‚Äôs environmental footprint ‚Äì enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action ‚Äì whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms ‚Äì survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center ‚Äì delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it‚Äôs routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we‚Äôre speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU‚Äôs Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their ‚Äúnow4tomorrow‚Äù program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. entry.title: SAP MDG: Validation - No Special Characters in Account Holder Field
entry.content:
Hi SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Note 01: This blog does not include execution screenshots.
Note 02: The entire code was developed and validated in the SANDBOX system, with results meeting expectations.

This post outlines a custom development approach in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG) to restrict the use of special characters in the Account Holder field. The validation logic is implemented using the enhancement framework via BADI: USMD_RULE_SERVICE, specifically through the method CHECK_ENTITY. This ensures data consistency and compliance with formatting standards during master data creation and change processes.

Prerequisite: A working knowledge of BADI USMD_RULE_SERVICE and ABAP development is required to follow this implementation.

Development Details

  • Message Class: ZMDGS_MSG_CLASS
  • Message Number: 002
  • Message Type: E
  • Message Text: The Account Holder field must not contain any special characters
  • BADI Method Implemented: IF_EX_USMD_RULE_SERVICE~CHECK_ENTITY 

    The validation logic is written directly in the method CHECK_ENTITY

    This ensures that when the Account Holder field is entered, the system validates the content to ensure it does not contain any special characters, and raises a custom message if invalid characters are found

Code:

 METHOD if_ex_usmd_rule_service~check_entity.
   DATA: lt_data        TYPE usmd_ts_data_entity,
         lt_bank_data   TYPE REF TO data,
         lt_msg         TYPE usmd_t_message,
         ls_msg         TYPE usmd_s_message,
         lv_fieldname   TYPE bu_koinh,
         lv_acc_holder TYPE char20.
   FIELD-SYMBOLS:
     <lt_bank>        TYPE SORTED TABLE,
     <ls_bank>        TYPE any,
     <lv_acc_holder> TYPE any.
   io_model->get_changed_fields(
     IMPORTING	
       et_entity_fieldname =  DATA(lt_fieldname)               
   )
   .
   LOOP AT lt_fieldname INTO DATA(ls_fieldname).
     lv_fieldname = ls_fieldname-fieldname.
     IF lv_fieldname = 'KOINH'.
       lv_acc_holder = lv_fieldname.
     ENDIF.
   ENDLOOP.
   IF lv_acc_holder = 'KOINH'.
     io_model->read_entity_data_all(
      EXPORTING
        i_fieldname      =       'BP_HEADER'           " Financial MDM: Field Name
        if_active        =         abap_false          " Financial MDM: General Indicator
    i_crequest       =            id_crequest          " Change Request
      IMPORTING
    et_message       =        lt_msg          " Messages
        et_data_entity   =      lt_data            " Data for Entity Types
    ).
     lt_bank_data = VALUE #( lt_data[ usmd_entity = 'BP_HEADER' usmd_entity_cont = 'BP_BKDTL' struct = 'KATTR' ]-r_t_data  OPTIONAL ).
     IF lt_bank_data IS NOT INITIAL.
       ASSIGN lt_bank_data->* TO <lt_bank>.
       IF <lt_bank> IS ASSIGNED.
         LOOP AT <lt_bank> ASSIGNING <ls_bank>.
           ASSIGN COMPONENT 'KOINH' OF STRUCTURE <ls_bank> TO <lv_acc_holder>.
           IF <lv_acc_holder> IS ASSIGNED AND
              <lv_acc_holder> IS NOT INITIAL AND                        
             <lv_acc_holder> CA '~`!@#$%^&*()-_+={}[]|\:;"<,>.?/'.
             et_message = VALUE #( BASE et_message ( fieldname = 'KOINH' msgid = 'ZMDGS_MESSAGE_CLS' msgno = '002' msgty = 'E' ) ).
           ENDIF.
         ENDLOOP.
       ENDIF.
     ENDIF.
   ENDIF.
 ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: S/4HANA transition for US Federal Agencies
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP ECC, the solution designed for US federal agencies relies on the Public Sector Management (PSM) component and special ledger functionality. Extensions to PSM were introduced to support federal-specific processes and reporting requirements, such as the Global Treasury Accounting Symbols (GTAS). GTAS are identification codes that classify financial transactions for the US federal government, consisting of a three-digit agency identifier, a period of fund availability, and a main account specifying the fund‚Äôs purpose.

A key feature for public sector entities in SAP ECC is the use of special purpose ledgers. Ledger 95 is specifically reserved for handling US federal government transactions and maintains the split processor configuration. Together with Ledgers 96 and 97, it manages budgetary information and postings for federal accounting requirements. Because this functionality exists only through special ledgers in ECC, most federal agencies remained on classic G/L without the ability to migrate to parallel ledgers in New G/L.

In SAP S/4HANA, the universal journal replaces the special ledger functionality, with the additional information from Ledgers 95, 96, and 97 available as federal ledgers in ACDOCA. This shift creates a significant migration challenge: federal agencies running on ECC cannot pursue brownfield conversions as it cannot bring the information in special ledgers to the universal journal. Meanwhile, greenfield implementations require major investments of time and budget, and they do not support migration of detailed historical transactional data‚Äîoften a regulatory requirement. Thus, neither brownfield nor greenfield options are viable.

Objective

The objective is to design a unique solution that meets the data migration needs of US federal agencies transitioning from ECC to S/4HANA. This solution must be able to extract splitting information from ECC special ledgers and apply it to the universal journal in S/4HANA, enabling migration of complete historical transactional data while ensuring business continuity and minimal change management.

Solution

SAP‚Äôs Data Management and Landscape Transformation (DMLT) organization has extended its Selective Data Transition (SDT) solution to specifically address the needs of US federal agencies. Often referred to as the ‚Äúthird option,‚Äù SDT provides an alternative to the traditional brownfield and greenfield approaches. It combines the strengths of both, offering flexibility in choosing the balance between reuse and redesign during S/4HANA transitions.

SDT leverages SAP DMLT‚Äôs proprietary software to design and execute tailor-made transitions. The key principle is separating application data from metadata (configuration, organizational structure, customizations, custom code, add-ons, etc.). The metadata is first used to create an S/4HANA shell, which can be deployed in a FedRAMP-authorized cloud environment.

During shell creation, federal-specific extensions such as the federal ledger, budgetary ledger, BCS, and budget period are configured. Once complete, the shell is ready to receive application data from the legacy ECC system.

For historical data migration, SDT tools have been extended to read selective history from ECC special ledgers and map it to the universal journal in S/4HANA. This allows complete transfer of historic transactional data, while ensuring alignment with redesigned federal-specific objects (e.g., mapping ECC tables FMUS* to S/4HANA tables PSGL*).

Note: Prior to data migration, the federal ledger and general ledger must be reconciled to ensure consistency.

Beyond federal extensions, SDT provides additional capabilities such as time-slicing historical data, harmonizing chart of accounts, and executing Customer-Vendor Integration (CVI) on the fly. Since the migration involves direct database loads, throughput is very high and optimized for large data volumes. SDT also includes advanced monitoring, error handling, and automated data validation, ensuring both efficiency and accuracy.

This approach is currently the only SAP-supported method for migrating historical transactional data from ECC to S/4HANA for US federal agencies.

Conclusion

SAP‚Äôs Selective Data Transition (SDT) offers a repeatable, automated, and secure solution for migrating historical transactional data from ECC to S/4HANA.

Key highlights of this solution include:

  • A hybrid approach that blends brownfield (reuse) and greenfield (redesign) strategies.
  • Extended SDT tools tailored for US federal agency requirements‚Äîthe only SAP solution that enables historical transactional data migration.
  • Compatibility with FedRAMP-authorized cloud environments.
  • Mapping of special ledgers (95, 96, 97) to the universal journal in S/4HANA.
  • Direct database load approach ensuring maximum business continuity and minimal change management.
  • Ability to selectively migrate historical data and apply business-specific transformations on the fly.
  • A structured deployment process involving at least three iterative rounds of migration and validation before production cutover.

This solution, available through SAP services, has already been successfully deployed and being deployed at multiple US federal agencies, enabling compliance, efficiency, and business continuity in their transition to S/4HANA.

 

SAP S/4HANA #USFed #DMLT #SDT

entry.title: Urgent Purchasing with Purchase Requisition Workflow in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud-1
entry.content:
Introduction:
In the world of procurement, speed can sometimes matter as much as compliance. Purchase Requisitions (PRs) are great for capturing business needs, but let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîthere are moments when waiting for the usual approval cycle simply isn‚Äôt an option. Maybe it‚Äôs a critical spare part, or maybe a project deadline is on the line. Whatever the case, you need a way to move things along quickly, without breaking governance rules.
SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud already gives us a pretty solid workflow framework for PRs. The catch, though, is that the standard setup doesn‚Äôt always capture those urgent, real-life situations. And that‚Äôs exactly where extensibility comes into play.
This blog shows you how to extend the workflow by adding a custom condition called ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing.‚Äù With this in place, whenever a PR item is marked as urgent, the system knows to push it straight to the right approvers‚Äîhelping you strike that tricky balance between speed and control.
Business Requirement:

  • Create a new Purchase Requisition (PR) approval workflow for Urgent Purchasing line items
  • Trigger the PR workflow only when this condition is true
  • Keep it flexible so it can be reused or adapted later

Process Flow Approach:
To meet this requirement, the standard extensibility options in SAP S/4HANA Cloud are utilized:

  • Custom Field ‚Üí A checkbox field at the PR item level to flag whether it‚Äôs ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù
  • Custom Logic ‚Üí To define and evaluate the start condition for the workflow
  • Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisition App ‚Üí To configure the condition into the workflow

Step 1: Creation of Custom Field for Purchase Requisitions:
Created a custom field for PR items using the Custom Fields app.
Process:
Go to Custom Fields ‚Üí click + (Create)

Fill in the following:

Business Context: Procurement: Purchase Requisition Item (MM_PURREQN_ITEM)

  • Label: Urgent Purchasing
  • Identifier: UrgentPurchasing
  • Tooltip: Urgent Purchasing
  • Type: Checkbox

After creation, the relevant UIs, reports, and analytics are enabled. The new field is added to the UI by adapting the screen and adding the new field.

Adding and Verifying the Custom Field in Purchase Requisition:
Click on Adapt UI ‚Üí Add the Custom Field ‚ÜíVerify the Custom Field ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù.

Step 2: Adding ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù As a Start Condition to the Workflow for Purchase Requisition:
This step defines the 'Urgent Purchasing' condition, so that it appears as a start condition in the workflow configuration.
Creating Custom logic for the ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù as below:
1. Process Flow: Go to Custom Logic App ‚Üí Click on Create ‚Üí Enter the Following Information.
2. Business Context: Procurement: Start and Pre-Conditions in Flexible Workflow
3. Extension Point: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_DEF
                                                                                Click on Step 2:
Click on the Add Button:
SCENARIO_ID: WS02000471
                                                                                Click on Step 3:
Implementation Description: Providing Additional Conditions for Scenarios
Implementation ID: YY1_PURCHASEREQUISITIONITEMS

            Click on Create and Publish
            Click on Open Editor and write the logic for ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù

Logic Code:
DATA: ls_condition LIKE LINE OF ct_condition,
ls_parameter LIKE LINE OF ct_parameter.

" Condition 1: Urgent Purchasing
ls_condition-id = '1'.
ls_condition-subject = 'Urgent Purchasing'.
ls_condition-type = if_swf_flex_ifs_condition_def=>cs_condtype-start_step.
APPEND ls_condition TO ct_condition.

ls_parameter-id = '1'.
ls_parameter-name = 'Urgent Purchasing'.
ls_parameter-shorttext = 'Urgent Purchasing'.
ls_parameter-xsd_type = if_swf_flex_ifs_condition_def=>cs_xstype-boolean.
ls_parameter-mandatory = abap_false.
APPEND ls_parameter TO ct_parameter.
Verifying the ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù at ‚ÄúStart Condition‚Äù of Purchase Requisition Workflow:

Step 3: Create Evaluation Custom Logic for Workflow
Once the condition existed, I needed logic to evaluate whether it was true for a given PR item.
Evaluation logic for the ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù is as follows:
1. Process Flow: Go to Custom Logic App ‚Üí Click on Create ‚Üí Enter the Following Information.
2. Business Context: Procurement: Start and Pre-Conditions in Flexible Workflow
3. Extension Point: SWF_WORKFLOW_CONDITION_EVAL

                                                                                  Click on Step 2
Click on the Add Button:
SCENARIO_ID: WS02000471
                                                                                 Click on Step 3
Implementation Description: Evaluation Logic for Purchase Requisition Workflow Condition
Implementation ID: YY1_EVALUATIONLOOPB_WPR

           Click on Create and Publish
          Click on Open Editor and write the logic for ‚ÄúUrgent Purchasing‚Äù

Logic Code for Evaluation:
" BAdI: Evaluation of Workflow Conditions for PR Item

DATA: ls_item TYPE i_purchaserequisitionitemapi01.

cv_is_true = abap_false.

" Ensure we have both PR and Item key
IF is_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_1 IS INITIAL OR
is_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_2 IS INITIAL.
RETURN.
ENDIF.

" Read the specific Purchase Requisition Item
SELECT SINGLE *
FROM i_purchaserequisitionitemapi01
WHERE purchaserequisition = @IS_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_1
AND purchaserequisitionitem = @IS_sap_object_node_type-sont_key_part_2
INTO @LS_item.
IF sy-subrc < > 0.
RETURN.
ENDIF.

" Condition 1: Urgent Purchasing
IF is_condition-condition_id = '1'.
" Adjust according to how the extension field stores the flag
IF ls_item-YY1_Urgent Purchasing = 'X'
OR ls_item-YY1_Urgent Purchasing = abap_true
OR ls_item-YY1_Urgent Purchasing = 'true'.
cv_is_true = abap_true.
ENDIF.
ENDIF.

Step 4: Creation of Workflow based on Custom Field
Use the Manage Workflows for Purchase Requisitions app to add the new start condition.

  • Navigate to the workflow scenario.
  • Add the custom condition Urgent Purchasing.
  • Define the workflow steps (e.g., approval by the Urgent Purchase owner).

Results:
After putting this together, PR workflows are now automatically triggered if an item is flagged as urgent purchasing.
Some key benefits:

  • 100% in-app extensibility, no modifications to SAP standard objects
  • Business-specific conditions integrated seamlessly with the standard workflow


Conclusion:
This small enhancement really shows the power of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud extensibility. By combining custom fields and logic with flexible workflows, it‚Äôs possible to adapt standard processes to unique business needs‚Äîwithout complex development.
If your organization faces similar challenges with urgent purchasing, compliance, or approval rules, this approach is worth considering.

Faisal Abbas

Application Cosnultant SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud

Navigator Business Solutions

entry.title: Minimizing SAP License Costs by optimizing SAP Authorizations with MOON Services
entry.content:
‚ÄúMOON ‚Äì Minimize Overhead, Optimize Need‚Äù

Efficient authorization management is crucial within the SAP environment for optimizing license costs. MOON Services aim to reduce authorizations to their necessary minimum, ensuring that what SAP users utilize is licensed, while optimizing unused authorizations. Let's explore the three essential MOON services: "MOON License Simulation", "MOON License Quickfix" and "MOON License Service powered by AIRC", each designed to enhance license management.

MOON License Simulation

MOON License Simulation focuses on precisely defining user license types in the SAP S/4HANA system through tailored authorizations to their essential minimum. This service enables companies to manage licenses efficiently and significantly reduce unnecessary costs.

Through simulation, customers can identify potential license cost optimizations when engaging in an authorization redesign with SAP Consulting. The service includes downloading usage data and calculating license costs for a new S/4HANA authorization concept against the requirements of the current STAR Service framework. Customers gain insight into possible license cost optimizations that can be achieved after an authorization redesign.


MOON License Quickfix

The MOON License Quickfix service offers rapid modifications to existing authorization structures, ensuring efficiency in license categorization. By analyzing current authorizations and making immediate role adjustments, companies can implement instant cost-saving measures.

entry.title: Innovations in Master Data Governance with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Continuing the blog series about innovations in SAP Master Data Governance (MDG), I'd like to share information about the key innovations in master data governance coming with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025.

Key Innovations include:

  • Continuous improvements in central governance (classic mode)‚Äã
  • Use of generative AI for governance processes (applies to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition only, innovations in classic mode and in cloud-ready mode)‚Äã
  • Improvements in data quality management (classic mode and cloud-ready mode)
  • Revamped data provider integration for the provisioning of business-partner reference data‚Äã (cloud-ready mode)
  • Application-agnostic legal hierarchies (business partner, cloud-ready mode)‚Äã

Key Innovations in Detail

Let me explain the innovations in more detail, according to the categories listed above. 

Continuous improvements in central governance (classic mode)‚Äã

This covers improvements in central governance of material, business partner, and financial data.

  • Material data:
    • Support for commodity codes comes integrated into the MDG UI as a separate User Interface Building Block (UIBB). Commodity codes from different numbering schemes can be assigned to a material and different valid from and to intervals can be maintained.
    • Input value help for characteristic (F4) now with assigned check table enables search either using the first 15 fields of the check table or Data Dictionary (DDIC) search help if it is assigned to the check table.
  • Financial data:
    • Inclusion of joint venture accounting fields as attributes of cost centers, profit centers, G/L accounts, and internal orders incl. validation checks and replication. 

      Use of joint venture accounting (JVA) fields as attributes of profit center
  • Propagation of changes done in an edition to the future edition to eliminate the need for repetitive updates across editions.

    Propagation of edition
  • Additionally, HANA-based search can be used as default search option.
  • Business partner data:
    • Enhanced client maintenance (de-central governance) scenarios depending on conditions such as create versus change scenarios, the actual client system sending the data, or the data to be processed.
    • Assignment of one or more data controllers and associated purpose to a business partner.
    • Enhanced IBAN converter (specifically for countries that require both an IBAN and a bank key) and alternative IBAN display format.
    • Document assignments on business partner level (create, change, or delete document assignments for business partners whether customer, supplier, or both in new Documents UIBB).
    • ‚Äã‚ÄãDisplay of the validity of sales areas and purchasing organizations in the input help.
    • Entry of maintain payment reasons for customers or suppliers for general or company code data and maintenance of recipient types for Customer Extended Withholding Tax data.

Maintenance of payment reasons for customers or suppliers and maintenance of recipient type for customer extended withholding tax data

Use of generative AI for governance processes

On the one hand, this covers the use of embedded AI for additional entities in assisted changes and summary of changes in central governance (when using classic mode). In particular, the inclusion of flex entities in generative AI-assisted changes in the central governance of business partner, material, and custom objects, and the inclusion edition-based entities in AI-generated summary of changes in the central governance of business partner, finance, material and custom objects.‚Äã

On the other‚Äã, it is about the use of Joule copilot to govern business partner data and run spot-checks on MDG process status (when using cloud-ready mode):

  • ‚ÄãNatural-language based prompts in Joule can be used to search, display, create, and change business partner data. 

Using Joule copilot for changing business partner data

  • Based on planned Joule content delivery, it is also planned to enable the search and display of specific information related to master data governance processes from November 2025 on.

Using Joule to search and display information about MDG processes

Improvements in data quality management (classic mode and cloud-ready mode)

There are various new features in the validation rules app for business partners and products. This includes capabilities to:

  • Copy validation rules
  • Create validation rules that check if a master data governance process has an attachment
  • Delete the validation rules' dependencies to other objects (for example, simulations, dimensions, or data quality evaluation runs) when deleting rules
  • Disable several validation rules at once
  • Filter for enabled usages, disabled usages and usages in general

Filtering validation rules for enabled usages

Revamped data provider integration for the provisioning of business-partner reference data‚Äã (cloud-ready mode)

This enables integration with an external data provider of your choice for automated use of high-quality data in governance processes using SAP Cloud Integration‚Äã.  With SAP Cloud Integration, you can connect any data provider to the business-partner domain, leveraging high-quality compliant reference data for searching and creating business partners.

Data provider integration

  1. Enter search term to check if the required business partner is already there.

  2. As this is not the case, click "Go" to connect with data provider reference data.

  3. Select the appropriate entry and create business partner with auto-populated fields.

Individually created SAP Cloud Integration packages provide you with the capability to connect with the data provider API and map between the data provider data model and the SAP data model of business partner. 

With a pre-defined SAP Cloud Integration package, accessible from SAP Business Hub, you can integrate your SAP Master Data Governance application efficiently and with less effort with the data provider Corporate Data Quality (CDQ). This plug-and-play package ensures default mapping from the data provider specific data model to the SAP business partner data model.

Application-agnostic legal hierarchies (business partner, cloud-ready mode)‚Äã

This new app provides governance of an aligned, application-agnostic legal business partner hierarchy representing the company ownership.  With this app you can:

  • Create, display, and delete business partner hierarchies‚Äã‚Äã
  • Create, edit, and delete nodes‚Äã‚Äã
  • Search for existing business partner hierarchies and nodes‚Äã‚Äã
  • Assign a business partner to a node

This way you can achieve a single source of truth for legal ownership data across all applications and support for compliance with regulatory and audit requirements while being able to make faster decisions based on the easy creation and updates of ownership structures.

More information

See also the presentation outlining the MDG delta content coming with SAP S/4HANA 2025 Cloud Private Edition .

To get the full picture of planned innovations in SAP Master Data Governance across the entire MDG solution portfolio, see the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

To stay up to date, simply follow the SAP Community Topic Page for SAP Master Data Governance and join the Q&A and discussion forum.

entry.title: From Customer Org. Chart to SAP Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus,
While diving deep into the world of SAP ERP for over 10 years, I wanted to share some of my findings and experience on a topic that can be a challenge for many of us: How to Design the Customer‚Äôs Organization Hierarchy into SAP Enterprise Structure.

It's great to deploy what the SAP best practice says, but from the customer perspective it‚Äôs very sensitive step as it‚Äôs reflecting the overall business decisions. I recognized this during my career in implementing SAP projects, and I hope my findings can help you out there for whom might be starting on a similar journey.

Bridging the Gap Between Customer's Org. Chart and SAP Enterprise Structure

We all have our company's organizational chart hanging somewhere in the office or in a PowerPoint file. It shows the customer's department hierarchy, who reports to whom, and how teams are structured.

But how do we take that familiar hierarchy and map it to SAP's world of Company Codes, Plants, and Purchasing Organizations? It's not always a one-to-one match, and that's where the complexity (and honestly, the fun!) begins.

I found an example of this in old SAP Community question from 2008. A community user laid out a detailed case study of a company with 4 factories, 3 regional distribution centers, 15 sales offices, in addition of an R&D team and project management team. It was a fantastic real world scenario that highlighted the tough question we often face.

"since material from Plant and RDC is being transferred to Branches and from there it is distributed to customers therefore the valuation of FG at BRANCH and RDC should be different as transportation cost, packing, unpacking etc cost should get added at Branch level. Therefore in case I make branch as Storage location, I will miss the valuation part while if I make them as Plant then there will be lot of documents get generated for each movement."

This is exactly the kind of practical dilemma that gets to the heart of enterprise structure design. It's a constant balancing act between financial accuracy and operational efficiency.

Understanding The SAP Organizational Units

Before we define and assign the SAP enterprise structure, we need to know exactly what of each SAP org. unit represents. It‚Äôs helpful to think of them in a hierarchical way, starting from the top.

  1. Client: the highest level in the SAP system hierarchy. Specifications that you make, or data that you enter at this level are valid for all company codes and for all other organizational structures. You therefore only need to make these specifications, or enter this data once. This ensures that the data is consistent.
  2. Company Codes: is the central organizational unit of external accounting within the SAP System. You must define at least one company code before implementing the Financial Accounting component. The business transactions relevant for Financial Accounting are entered, saved, and evaluated at company code level.
  3. Plant: organizational unit serving to subdivide an enterprise according to production, procurement, maintenance, and materials planning aspects. It is a place where either materials are produced or goods and services provided.
  4. Purchasing Organizations and Purchasing Groups: An organizational unit subdividing an enterprise according to the requirements of Purchasing. It procures materials and services, negotiates conditions of purchase with vendors, and is responsible for such transactions. A purchasing group is a key for a buyer or group of buyers in SAP ERP. It is responsible for the procurement of a material or class of materials, and is the principal channel for a company's dealings with its suppliers.

Organizational Unit

Key Characteristics

Typical Use Cases

Client

Highest level, represents entire corporate group

One per SAP system

Company Code

Legal entity with independent financial statements

Subsidiaries, country operations

Plant

Operational unit where business activities occur

Factories, warehouses, sales offices

Storage Location

Physical storage area within a Plant

Warehouse sections, storage areas

Purchasing Org

Defines procurement scope and authority

Centralized or decentralized procurement

Purchasing Group

Actual procurement team or buyer

Commodity teams, regional buyers

A Visual Approach to Mapping

I'm a visual learner, so diagrams really help me solidify these concepts. I've created a couple of diagrams to illustrate how a typical departmental structure might map to SAP organizational units, and how those units relate to each other.
Here's a conceptual mapping from real-world departments to SAP units:

And here's a more detailed example of what a complete SAP organizational hierarchy might looks like, incorporating multiple company codes, plants, and purchasing organizations:

My Key Takeaways and Learned Lessons

After implementing a lot of SAP projects, here are some advices I have heard from my leaders:

Start with the "Why," Not the "What." Don't just create organizational units because they exist in your company. Think about your business processes and reporting requirements first. What do the customer need to see in his financial reports? How he manage his inventory? How do he want to analyze his procurement activities and expenses? The answers to these questions should guide you WHAT is the correct design decisions.

  1. The Plant is probably the most versatile org. unit in SAP. I've seen Plants used to represent everything from manufacturing facilities to service centers. Don't be afraid to think creatively about how to use Plants to model your business operations. Just remember that each Plant needs to be assigned to a Company Code, so plan accordingly. And remember that SAP defines the plant as a logistics organizational element that is used by all the logistics modules. The plant is assigned to a company code that may have many plants assigned to it. A plant is typically configured in conjunction with the company code and valuation area due to tax rules and regulations.
    Depending on the role the plant has in the organization, a plant can be defined for the following purposes:
    • In Sales and Distribution (SD), a location from which finished goods and materials are stored and distributed.
    • A location from which services are rendered.
    • Materials Management (MM), a location where material flow is managed and stock requirements are managed from both the inbound and outbound perspectives.
    • A location where material stock is consumed, planned, and purchased.
    • A manufacturing facility where materials are produced, as in Production Planning (PP).
  2. Purchasing org. structure has a huge impact on your procurement processes, approval workflows, and reporting. I learned that the hard way when we had to redesign our purchasing structure because we hadn't thought through the implications properly. Take time to understand whether a centralized or decentralized org. unit makes the most sense for your company.
  3. Plan for Growth and Change, Your first design probably won't be perfect, and your business will expand over time. Build flexibility into your design where possible, and don't be afraid to iterate, I've seen too many implementations get stuck because they tried to create the "perfect" structure from day one instead of starting with something good and improving it over time.
  4. Document Your Decisions, This might seem obvious, but document not just what you designed, but why you designed it. think in future questions, when someone ask why the regional sales offices are defined as plants instead of storage locations, you'll be glad that you wrote your reasoning.

Important Considerations

in past implementations i've encountered some comments from the customer that might help you think through your own design:

  1. Multi-Country Operations: If the customer operates in multiple countries, you'll likely need separate company codes for each country due to legal and tax requirements, but you might be able to share plants across company codes for operational efficiency.
  2. Shared Transactions: If the customer has shared service centers (like a centralized IT department or shared warehouse), think carefully about how to define and assign these on SAP, sometimes they're best represented as separate org. units, sometimes as cost centers within existing org. units.
  3. Acquisitions and Divestitures: If the company invest in other legal entities by frequently acquires or divests business units, design the SAP structure to make these transitions easier, this might mean keeping acquired companies as separate company codes initially, even if the customer plan to integrate them later.

Summery

SAP Enterprise Structure design is a piece of art, a part of business administration science, and a part of overall company growth.
There's no one "correct" way to do it, but there are definitely wrong ways, the key here is to understand customer business requirements, think through the implications of your design, and be prepared to adapt as you may learn later.

I hope my thoughts and findings has been helpful for you, and I'm always learning new things about SAP organizational structures, so I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences.

  • What challenges have you faced when mapping customer's organization in SAP?
  • What advice would you give to SAP community members or for a someone has just starting out?
  • Have you encountered any particularly creative or unusual organizational structure designs?
